title: No-Cloning Theorem
formal_statement: There is no unitary operation that can copy an arbitrary unknown quantum state. For any quantum state |ψ⟩, no process can create |ψ⟩|ψ⟩ from |ψ⟩|0⟩ for all |ψ⟩.
plain_language: You cannot make a perfect copy of an unknown quantum state. Unlike classical information, quantum information cannot be duplicated.
assumptions_scope: Quantum state is unknown (not in a known basis)
Perfect copying required (high fidelity, not approximate)
No measurement allowed before copying (measurement collapses state)
typical_traps: Promising a quantum Xerox machine or perfect quantum memory backup
Confusing classical bits (which can be copied) with qubits
Not recognizing that measurement to copy destroys superposition
Assuming quantum information behaves like classical information

examples: Clone states from pre-agreed orthogonal set
Prepare multiple identical states from known preparation procedure
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Only works when state is known in advance; not useful for arbitrary quantum information

examples: Quantum state tomography (requires many copies, measurements)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Imperfect copies; requires resources (many copies or ancilla systems); fidelity-probability tradeoff

escape_hatches.description: Use quantum teleportation instead of cloning
examples: Quantum error correction (protects one logical qubit)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: State is transferred, not duplicated; requires entanglement and classical communication

test_or_check: Check if the claim requires perfect duplication of arbitrary unknown quantum states. If yes, and no measurement or prior knowledge assumed, flag as conflicting with no-cloning theorem.
references: Wootters, W. K., & Zurek, W. H. (1982). A Single Quantum Cannot be Cloned. Nature, 299(5886), 802-803. doi:10.1038/299802a0
Dieks, D. (1982). Communication by EPR devices. Physics Letters A, 92(6), 271-272.
notes: The no-cloning theorem is fundamental to quantum cryptography (ensures eavesdropping is detectable) and quantum information theory. It distinguishes quantum information from classical information.
